senses.de: A system of words, letters, or symbols replacing ordinary language, used for secret or short communication.
senses.ex: She wrote the note in code so only her friend could understand it.

Tips.title: Secret Messages
Tips.description: Used when people want to hide information from others.

Tips.title: Brief Instructions
Tips.description: Simplified language that conveys complex information quickly.
Tips.example: Pilots use code for efficient communication.

senses.de: A set of rules or principles that people follow.
senses.ex: The knight lived by a code of honor.

Tips.title: Guiding Rules
Tips.description: Refers to a set of rules guiding behavior or dress in contexts like work or school.
Tips.example: Most companies have a code of ethics.

Tips.title: Professional Expectations
Tips.description: Implies expected standards in a professional environment.
Tips.example: The hospital has a strict dress code.

senses.de: A system of signals used to represent letters or numbers.
senses.ex: Morse code is a system using dots and dashes.

Tips.title: Specific Abbreviations
Tips.description: A shorthand representation, often used by professionals to save time.

Tips.title: Not Language Specific
Tips.description: Can be understood across different languages and cultures.

senses.de: A set of instructions for a computer.
senses.ex: He wrote the code for the new software.

Tips.title: Creating Software
Tips.description: Refers to the specific task of programming computer applications.
Tips.example: She codes in C++ for software development.

Tips.title: Technical Knowledge
Tips.description: Requires understanding of programming languages and logic.
Tips.example: You need to learn coding to develop apps.

senses.de: A system of symbols and rules used to represent instructions to a computer.
senses.ex: HTML is a code used to create websites.

Tips.title: Web Development
Tips.description: The code that structures and styles websites.
Tips.example: HTML code defines the structure of web pages.

Tips.title: Not Just Text
Tips.description: Combines text with logic to build interactive elements.
Tips.example: Website code can create animations and forms.

senses.de: To write code for a computer program.
senses.ex: He was up all night coding the new website.

Tips.title: Modern Skillset
Tips.description: Considered an essential skill in many technology jobs today.
Tips.example: Young professionals often code as part of their job.

Tips.title: Career Opportunities
Tips.description: Learning to code opens up numerous paths in the tech industry.
Tips.example: She got a job in tech after learning to code.

Algorithm.wordDefinition:
An algorithm is a series of steps that you follow to solve a problem while code is the implementation of that algorithm in a particular programming language.

Think of algorithms as the recipe to bake a cake - there are a set of steps you need to take in order to achieve the end result.

The algorithm is the plan, and code is the execution of that plan.

Code is like the actual baking of the cake. It's the implementation of the steps that you've written in an algorithm in a language that a computer can understand.

An algorithm is a process or set of instructions, while code is the implementation of those instructions in a particular programming language.

Algorithms are used in planning and designing, while code is used in development and execution.

Cipher.wordDefinition:
A cipher is a way to hide a message by scrambling the letters or characters to make the message unreadable to anyone except the intended recipient.

A cipher requires a specific key or algorithm to decode the message. An example of a cipher is the Caesar cipher, which shifts each letter of the message a certain number of spaces down the alphabet.

In summary, codes are used to represent words or phrases to make communication more efficient, while ciphers are used to hide messages from unwanted readers.

Key.wordDefinition:
Key refers to a small tool or device that allows access to something or unlocks something. Keys are commonly used to open doors or locks, or to start a car or engine, among other things.

In short, codes are used to represent information and require decoding, while keys are used to unlock or access something physically.

Language.wordDefinition:
In broad terms, the word code refers to a set of instructions that a computer can understand and execute, while the word language describes the human-readable aspect of programming.

In other words, a code is a machine-readable set of instructions, whereas a language is a human-readable set of instructions.

Language is often used more broadly to refer to the overall structure and syntax of a programming language.

Overall, both code and language are essential components of modern software development, and are used extensively in a wide range of applications, from web development to scientific computing to video game design.

Password.wordDefinition:
A password is a secret word or phrase that is used to gain access to something like an account or device. It's like a key that unlocks a door.

Passwords are used to protect information or prevent unauthorized access.

A code is used to give instructions or control something, while a password is used to gain access to something. Codes are commonly used in programming, while passwords are used to protect online accounts, personal devices, and other sensitive information.

Programme.wordDefinition:
Code typically refers to the instructions that a programmer writes to make a computer do something, like solving a math problem or displaying a picture.

Programme usually refers to a larger, more complex software project that can include many different pieces of code.

You can think of code as the building blocks of a software project, while programme refers to the overall structure and design of the project itself.

So a programmer might write a lot of code as part of a larger programme, but the code itself is just one piece of the bigger picture.

Protocol.wordDefinition:
Protocol, on the other hand, refers to a set of rules or guidelines that dictate how people should behave in certain situations.

For example, there might be a protocol for how to behave at a formal dinner, or a protocol for how to handle a medical emergency.

Protocols are used in a variety of different fields, including medicine, diplomacy, and social situations.

In short, codes are used in machines to tell them what to do, while protocols are used in human interactions to guide behavior.

quotes.Text: The brain is behind the really big questions we have. Who am I, what is my identity? What is that based on? If memories are encoded in connectomes, your personality might be in your connectome. If that's the case, that's the basis of your uniqueness as a person.

quotes.Text: For me, growing up coding and computers and video games wasn't something that was cool, but it was something that I was always passionate about. I never let the fact that that wasn't something that was cool take me away from it.

quotes.Text: Crime writers adore islands. We love the sense of being trapped within a community apart, where normal codes of behavior, if not ignored, can be allowed to slip.

quotes.Name: Sharon Bolton

quotes.Text: I'm curious how people build up the codes that they live their life by, and how they come to think that that's the best way for them to function.

quotes.Text: We think coding should be required in every school because it's as important as any kind of second language.
